question_text:
If $\begin{vmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{vmatrix} = 4,$ then find
\[\begin{vmatrix} a & 7a + 3b \\ c & 7c  +3d \end{vmatrix}.\]
response:
Since we know that $ad - bc = 4$, it follows by the definition of determinant that

$$
\begin{align*}
\begin{vmatrix} a & 7a + 3b \\ c & 7c+3d \end{vmatrix}&=\begin{vmatrix} a & b\\c&d\end{vmatrix}\cdot\begin{vmatrix}1&7a+3b\\0&7c+3d-7(a+3b/c)\end{vmatrix}\\
&=4(7c + 3d - 7a -21b/c)\\
&=28c+12d-28a-21b.
\end{align*}
$$

However, this expression is also the value of $ad - bc$ which we know is equal to 4. This shows that $\boxed{\begin{vmatrix} a & 7a + 3b \\ c & 7c+3d \end{vmatrix}=0}$
